instruction: For each one of the following scenarios please select the most likely diagnosis:
questions: A 61-year-old woman with a history of cardiac problems develops hearing loss after a prolonged admission in hospital. Drug toxicity is suspected.
R 78-pvri-fcu dre tfdgcrzej fw uzwwztlckcp wfccfnzex tfemvijrkzfej. Yzj nzwv jrpj yv yrj kyv KM klievu lg kff cflu. Rluzfdvkip jyfnj jvejfizevlirc yvrizex cfjj rk kyv yzxyvi wivhlvetzvj.
R 37-pvri-fcu tvccf gcrpvi tfdgcrzej fw r kyivv dfeky yzjkfip fw mvikzxf reu yvrizex cfjj fe kyv cvwk jzuv. Fe vordzerkzfe yv yrj re rsjvek tfievrc ivwcvo fe kyv cvwk vpv.
question: A 61-year-old woman with a history of cardiac problems develops hearing loss after a prolonged admission in hospital. Drug toxicity is suspected.
title: Deafness
body:
The most common causes of hearing loss are ear wax, otitis media and otitis externa. The table below details some of the characteristic features of other causes:

ConditionKey features
PresbycusisPresbycusis describes age-related sensorineural hearing loss. Patients may describe difficulty following conversations

Audiometry shows bilateral high-frequency hearing loss
OtosclerosisAutosomal dominant, replacement of normal bone by vascular spongy bone. Onset is usually at 20-40 years - features include:
  • conductive deafness
  • tinnitus
  • tympanic membrane - 10% of patients may have a 'flamingo tinge', caused by hyperaemia
  • positive family history
Glue earAlso known as otitis media with effusion
  • peaks at 2 years of age
  • hearing loss is usually the presenting feature (glue ear is the commonest cause of conductive hearing loss and elective surgery in childhood)
  • secondary problems such as speech and language delay, behavioural or balance problems may also be seen
Meniere's diseaseMore common in middle-aged adults
  • recurrent episodes of vertigo, tinnitus and hearing loss (sensorineural). Vertigo is usually the prominent symptom
  • a sensation of aural fullness or pressure is now recognised as being common
  • other features include nystagmus and a positive Romberg test
  • episodes last minutes to hours
Drug ototoxicityExamples include aminoglycosides (e.g. Gentamicin), furosemide, aspirin and a number of cytotoxic agents
Noise damageWorkers in heavy industry are particularly at risk

Hearing loss is bilateral and typically is worse at frequencies of 3000-6000 Hz
Acoustic neuroma (more correctly called vestibular schwannomas)Features can be predicted by the affected cranial nerves
  • cranial nerve VIII: hearing loss, vertigo, tinnitus
  • cranial nerve V: absent corneal reflex
  • cranial nerve VII: facial palsy

Bilateral acoustic neuromas are seen in neurofibromatosis type 2
media:
Understanding the Causes of Hearing Loss
Zero To Finals - YouTube142

questions:
A 53-year-old man presents complaining of an itchy scalp and dandruff. On examination he is noted to have the following lesions on his scalp, along with similar lesions behind his ears and around his nose.

© Image used on license from DermNet NZ

He has tried 'Head and Shoulders' and 'Neutrogen T-gel' but with poor results. Which one of the following is the most appropriate treatment for his scalp?
notes:
The most appropriate treatment for this patient's scalp is topical ketoconazole. The clinical presentation of an itchy scalp, dandruff, and eczema on the scalp, behind the ears, and around the nose suggests a diagnosis of seborrhoeic dermatitis. Seborrhoeic dermatitis is a common inflammatory skin condition that mainly affects areas rich in sebaceous glands such as the scalp, face, and upper trunk. It is thought to be related to an overgrowth of yeast-like fungi from the genus Malassezia, which are part of the normal skin flora.

Topical ketoconazole is an antifungal medication that targets Malassezia species and helps reduce inflammation in seborrhoeic dermatitis. It can be applied as a shampoo or cream depending on the affected area. In this case, since the patient has already tried other shampoos without success and his symptoms involve both his scalp and face, topical ketoconazole would be suitable to manage his condition.

Topical hydrocortisone may provide some relief from itching and inflammation associated with seborrhoeic dermatitis; however, it does not target the underlying fungal overgrowth contributing to the condition. Additionally, long-term use of topical corticosteroids on facial skin can cause thinning of the skin and other side effects.

Topical dermovate, which contains clobetasol propionate (a potent corticosteroid), may also help reduce inflammation but carries similar risks as hydrocortisone regarding long-term use on facial skin. Moreover, it does not address the fungal component of seborrhoeic dermatitis.

Topical selenium sulphide is another antifungal agent that may be used in treating seborrhoeic dermatitis. However, it is not as effective as ketoconazole and can cause skin irritation, making it a less suitable option for this patient who has already tried other shampoos without success.

Oral terbinafine is an antifungal medication that is primarily used to treat dermatophyte infections such as tinea pedis (athlete's foot), tinea corporis (ringworm), and tinea capitis (scalp ringworm). It is not typically prescribed for seborrhoeic dermatitis, as its efficacy against Malassezia species is limited compared to topical ketoconazole. Additionally, oral antifungal therapy carries a risk of systemic side effects and potential drug interactions, making it a less desirable option in this case.

title: Seborrhoeic dermatitis in adults
body:
Seborrhoeic dermatitis in adults is a chronic dermatitis thought to be caused by an inflammatory reaction related to a proliferation of a normal skin inhabitant, a fungus called Malassezia furfur (formerly known as Pityrosporum ovale). It is common, affecting around 2% of the general population.

Features
  • eczematous lesions on the sebum-rich areas: scalp (may cause dandruff), periorbital, auricular and nasolabial folds
  • otitis externa and blepharitis may develop


Associated conditions include
  • HIV
  • Parkinson's disease

Scalp disease management
  • the first-line treatment is ketoconazole 2% shampoo
  • over the counter preparations containing zinc pyrithione ('Head & Shoulders') and tar ('Neutrogena T/Gel') may be used if ketoconazole is not appropriate or acceptable to the person
  • selenium sulphide and topical corticosteroid may also be useful

Face and body management
  • topical antifungals: e.g. ketoconazole
  • topical steroids: best used for short periods
  • difficult to treat - recurrences are common
concept: Seborrhoeic dermatitis - first-line treatment is topical ketoconazole
links:
DermNet NZ216
Overview and pictures of seborrhoeic dermatitis

340.concept_text: Seborrhoeic dermatitis - first-line treatment is topical ketoconazole

8750.concept_text: An itchy rash affecting the face and scalp distribution is commonly caused by seborrhoeic dermatitis

8942.concept_text: Otitis externa and blepharitis are common complications of seborrhoeic dermatitis

8944.concept_text: Parkinson's disease is associated with seborrhoeic dermatitis

questions:
A 58-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a three-week history of worsening dry cough, dyspnoea, and intermittent fevers. She reports no sputum production or chest pain. She has a history of rheumatoid arthritis, which is managed with methotrexate, folic acid and naproxen. On examination, she is afebrile with an oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. Auscultation reveals bibasilar crackles. A chest X-ray shows bilateral interstitial infiltrates.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
notes:
Drug-induced pneumonitis is correct. Methotrexate-induced pneumonitis is a known side effect of methotrexate therapy, presenting with dry cough, dyspnoea, and fever. The subacute progression of symptoms (over three weeks), absence of infection, and X-ray findings of bilateral interstitial infiltrates strongly support this diagnosis. Early recognition is essential, as discontinuation of methotrexate and initiation of corticosteroids can be necessary.

Acute bronchitis is incorrect. Acute bronchitis usually presents with a productive cough, sometimes following an upper respiratory tract infection. The patient’s dry cough, bibasilar crackles, and bilateral interstitial infiltrates on X-ray are inconsistent with typical acute bronchitis. Moreover, it is uncommon for acute bronchitis to cause symptoms that persist for several weeks.

Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) is incorrect. PCP is a possible diagnosis, especially in immunosuppressed patients on methotrexate. Still, it typically occurs in those who are severely immunocompromised (e.g., patients with HIV/AIDS or those on high-dose corticosteroids). The patient is not profoundly immunosuppressed, making methotrexate-induced pneumonitis more likely than PCP in this case.

Pulmonary rheumatoid nodules is incorrect. Pulmonary rheumatoid nodules are a manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis but are generally asymptomatic unless they cavitate or cause complications such as pneumothorax or infection. They are unlikely to cause the subacute symptoms of cough, dyspnoea, and fever seen in this patient. Additionally, rheumatoid nodules do not typically cause interstitial infiltrates on chest X-ray.

Sarcoidosis is incorrect. Sarcoidosis can present with interstitial infiltrates and respiratory symptoms. However, it usually affects younger patients and is less likely in the context of recent methotrexate use. Additionally, sarcoidosis is often associated with bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, which is not mentioned in this case. The patient's history of rheumatoid arthritis and methotrexate makes methotrexate-induced pneumonitis a more likely cause.

What is the most likely diagnosis?

title: Methotrexate
body:
Methotrexate is an antimetabolite that inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, an enzyme essential for the synthesis of purines and pyrimidines. It is considered an 'important' drug as whilst it can be very effective in controlling disease the side-effects may be potentially life-threatening - careful prescribing and close monitoring is essential.

The mechanism of action of methotrexate is complicated and can depend on dose:
  • core mechanism of action:
    • folate analogue → competitively inhibits dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR).
    • this prevents conversion of dihydrofolate → tetrahydrofolate, which is essential for purine and thymidylate synthesis.
    • result = ↓ DNA and RNA synthesis, especially in rapidly dividing cells.
  • at low weekly doses (rheumatology, e.g. rheumatoid arthritis, psoriasis):
    • immunomodulatory effect is more important than direct cytotoxicity.
    • inhibits AICAR transformylase → accumulation of adenosine, a potent anti-inflammatory mediator.
    • suppresses T-cell activation and cytokine production.
    • reduces proliferation of lymphocytes in synovium/skin.
  • at high doses (oncology use)
    • anti-proliferative / cytotoxic effect
    • direct inhibition of nucleotide synthesis → apoptosis of rapidly dividing malignant cells.
    • often given with folinic acid (leucovorin) rescue to protect normal tissues.

Indications
  • inflammatory arthritis, especially rheumatoid arthritis
  • psoriasis
  • some chemotherapy acute lymphoblastic leukaemia

Adverse effects
  • mucositis
  • myelosuppression
  • pneumonitis
    • the most common pulmonary manifestation
    • similar disease pattern to hypersensitivity pneumonitis secondary to inhaled organic antigens
    • typically develops within a year of starting treatment, either acutely or subacutely
    • presents with non-productive cough, dyspnoea, malaise, fever
  • liver fibrosis

Whilst methotrexate was previously thought to cause pulmonary fibrosis recent longer term follow up studies do not support this association.

Pregnancy
  • women should avoid pregnancy for at least 6 months after treatment has stopped
  • the BNF also advises that men using methotrexate need to use effective contraception for at least 6 months after treatment

Prescribing methotrexate
  • methotrexate is a drug with a high potential for patient harm. It is therefore important that you are familiar with guidelines relating to its use
  • methotrexate is taken weekly, rather than daily
  • FBC, U&E and LFTs need to be regularly monitored. The Committee on Safety of Medicines recommend 'FBC and renal and LFTs before starting treatment and repeated weekly until therapy stabilised, thereafter patients should be monitored every 2-3 months'
  • folic acid 5mg once weekly should be co-prescribed, taken more than 24 hours after methotrexate dose
  • the starting dose of methotrexate is 7.5 mg weekly (source: BNF)
  • only one strength of methotrexate tablet should be prescribed (usually 2.5 mg)

Interactions
  • avoid prescribing trimethoprim or co-trimoxazole concurrently - increases risk of marrow aplasia
  • high-dose aspirin increases the risk of methotrexate toxicity secondary to reduced excretion

Methotrexate toxicity
  • the treatment of choice is folinic acid
concept: Methotrexate may cause pneumonitis - typically presents with cough, dyspnoea and fever
links:
British Society for Rheumatology108
2017 Guideline for the prescription and monitoring of non-biologic disease-modifying anti-rheumatic drugs


British Association of Dermatologists118
2016 Guidelines for the safe and effective prescribing of methotrexate for skin disease


BNF168
Methotrexate
media:
Methotrexate - Pharmacology (DMARDs, mechanism of action, side effects)
Armando Hasudungan - YouTube54

894.concept_text: The concurrent use of methotrexate and trimethoprim containing antibiotics may cause bone marrow suppression and severe or fatal pancytopaenia

3187.concept_text: Co-trimoxazole contains trimethoprim and therefore should never be prescribed with methotrexate

8271.concept_text: Methotrexate may cause pneumonitis - typically presents with cough, dyspnoea and fever

8272.concept_text: Methotrexate may cause hepatotoxicity - monitor LFTs

questions:
A 26-year-old woman comes to see her GP after complaining of weight gain, hair loss, constipation and feelings of being cold all the time. She is also amenorrhoeic and struggled to breastfeed after birth. She has no significant past medical history but during her daughter's birth she suffered from a large amount of blood loss and subsequent hypovolaemic shock which required a 6 weeks hospital stay.

Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
notes:
Sheehan's syndrome (otherwise known as postpartum hypopituitarism) is a reduction in the function of the pituitary gland following ischaemic necrosis due to hypovolaemic shock following birth. The symptoms can be varied due to the damage in the pituitary and can sometimes take years to develop.

This patient has amenorrhoea, problems with milk production and hypothyroidism, which point towards pituitary dysfunction. Her complicated birth allows for the diagnosis of Sheehan's syndrome.
question:
A 26-year-old woman comes to see her GP after complaining of weight gain, hair loss, constipation and feelings of being cold all the time. She is also amenorrhoeic and struggled to breastfeed after birth. She has no significant past medical history but during her daughter's birth she suffered from a large amount of blood loss and subsequent hypovolaemic shock which required a 6 weeks hospital stay.

Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
question_notes:
Sheehan's syndrome (otherwise known as postpartum hypopituitarism) is a reduction in the function of the pituitary gland following ischaemic necrosis due to hypovolaemic shock following birth. The symptoms can be varied due to the damage in the pituitary and can sometimes take years to develop.

This patient has amenorrhoea, problems with milk production and hypothyroidism, which point towards pituitary dysfunction. Her complicated birth allows for the diagnosis of Sheehan's syndrome.
title: Amenorrhoea
body:
Amenorrhoea may be divided into:
  • primary: defined as the failure to establish menstruation by 15 years of age in girls with normal secondary sexual characteristics (such as breast development), or by 13 years of age in girls with no secondary sexual characteristics
  • secondary: cessation of menstruation for 3-6 months in women with previously normal and regular menses, or 6-12 months in women with previous oligomenorrhoea


Causes

Primary amenorrhoeaSecondary amenorrhoea (after excluding pregnancy)
  • gonadal dysgenesis (e.g. Turner's syndrome) - the most common causes
  • testicular feminisation
  • congenital malformations of the genital tract
  • functional hypothalamic amenorrhoea (e.g. secondary to anorexia)
  • congenital adrenal hyperplasia
  • imperforate hymen
  • hypothalamic amenorrhoea (e.g. secondary stress, excessive exercise)
  • polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS)
  • hyperprolactinaemia
  • premature ovarian failure
  • thyrotoxicosis*
  • Sheehan's syndrome
  • Asherman's syndrome (intrauterine adhesions)

    • Investigation and management

    Initial investigations
    • exclude pregnancy with urinary or serum bHCG
    • full blood count, urea & electrolytes, coeliac screen, thyroid function tests
    • gonadotrophins
      • low levels indicate a hypothalamic cause where as raised levels suggest an ovarian problem (e.g. Premature ovarian failure)
      • raised if gonadal dysgenesis (e.g. Turner's syndrome)
    • prolactin
    • androgen levels
      • raised levels may be seen in PCOS
    • oestradiol

    Management
    • primary amenorrhoea:
      • investigate and treat any underlying cause
      • with primary ovarian insufficiency due to gonadal dysgenesis (e.g. Turner's syndrome) are likely to benefit from hormone replacement therapy (e.g. to prevent osteoporosis etC)
    • secondary amenorrhoea
      • exclude pregnancy, lactation, and menopause (in women 40 years of age or older)
      • treat the underlying cause

    *hypothyroidism may also cause amenorrhoea
media:
Amenorrhoea
Osmosis - YouTube103

3307.concept_text: Secondary amenorrhoea: low-level gonadotrophins indicate a hypothalamic causes

11380.concept_text: Raised FSH/LH in primary amenorrhoea - consider gonadal dysgenesis (e.g. Turner's syndrome)

questions: Which of the following conditions is inherited in an autosomal recessive fashion?
notes:
The correct answer is Friedreich's ataxia, which is a neurodegenerative disorder inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. It is caused by mutations in the FXN gene, which codes for the protein frataxin. Both copies of the gene must be mutated for the condition to manifest, which is characteristic of autosomal recessive inheritance. The condition typically presents in childhood or adolescence with progressive ataxia, loss of proprioception, and cardiomyopathy.

Hypokalaemic periodic paralysis is actually inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. It results from mutations in genes coding for calcium or sodium ion channels, most commonly the CACNA1S gene. Only one copy of the mutated gene is needed for the condition to manifest.

Adult polycystic kidney disease is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. It is caused by mutations in either the PKD1 or PKD2 genes. The condition leads to the formation of multiple cysts in the kidneys and can present with hypertension, haematuria, and progressive renal failure.

Huntington's disease is a classic example of autosomal dominant inheritance. It is caused by a trinucleotide repeat expansion in the HTT gene. The condition shows complete penetrance, meaning that everyone who inherits the mutated gene will develop the disease if they live long enough.

Ehlers-Danlos syndrome typically shows autosomal dominant inheritance, although some rare subtypes can be autosomal recessive or X-linked. The most common form, hypermobile EDS, is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. The condition affects collagen synthesis and results in joint hypermobility, skin hyperextensibility, and tissue fragility.
question: Which of the following conditions is inherited in an autosomal recessive fashion?
question_notes:
The correct answer is Friedreich's ataxia, which is a neurodegenerative disorder inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. It is caused by mutations in the FXN gene, which codes for the protein frataxin. Both copies of the gene must be mutated for the condition to manifest, which is characteristic of autosomal recessive inheritance. The condition typically presents in childhood or adolescence with progressive ataxia, loss of proprioception, and cardiomyopathy.

Hypokalaemic periodic paralysis is actually inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. It results from mutations in genes coding for calcium or sodium ion channels, most commonly the CACNA1S gene. Only one copy of the mutated gene is needed for the condition to manifest.

Adult polycystic kidney disease is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. It is caused by mutations in either the PKD1 or PKD2 genes. The condition leads to the formation of multiple cysts in the kidneys and can present with hypertension, haematuria, and progressive renal failure.

Huntington's disease is a classic example of autosomal dominant inheritance. It is caused by a trinucleotide repeat expansion in the HTT gene. The condition shows complete penetrance, meaning that everyone who inherits the mutated gene will develop the disease if they live long enough.

Ehlers-Danlos syndrome typically shows autosomal dominant inheritance, although some rare subtypes can be autosomal recessive or X-linked. The most common form, hypermobile EDS, is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. The condition affects collagen synthesis and results in joint hypermobility, skin hyperextensibility, and tissue fragility.
title: Autosomal recessive conditions
body:
Autosomal recessive conditions are often thought to be 'metabolic' as opposed to autosomal dominant conditions being 'structural', notable exceptions:
  • some 'metabolic' conditions such as Hunter's and G6PD are X-linked recessive whilst others such as hyperlipidemia type II and hypokalemic periodic paralysis are autosomal dominant
  • some 'structural' conditions such as ataxia telangiectasia and Friedreich's ataxia are autosomal recessive

The following conditions are autosomal recessive:
  • Albinism
  • Ataxic telangiectasia
  • Congenital adrenal hyperplasia
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Cystinuria
  • Familial Mediterranean Fever
  • Fanconi anaemia
  • Friedreich's ataxia
  • Gilbert's syndrome*
  • Glycogen storage disease
  • Haemochromatosis
  • Homocystinuria
  • Lipid storage disease: Tay-Sach's, Gaucher, Niemann-Pick
  • Mucopolysaccharidoses: Hurler's
  • PKU
  • Sickle cell anaemia
  • Thalassaemias
  • Wilson's disease

*this is still a matter of debate and many textbooks will list Gilbert's as autosomal dominant
concept:
Autosomal recessive conditions are 'metabolic' - exceptions: inherited ataxias

Autosomal dominant conditions are 'structural' - exceptions: Gilbert's, hyperlipidaemia type II

6466.concept_text: Sickle cell anaemia is autosomal recessive

questions:
A 16-year-old receives regular blood transfusions since she was diagnosed with beta-thalassaemia major as a baby.

What medication should she also be taking alongside her infusions?
notes:
Patients with beta thalassaemia-major need regular transfusions from birth. As a result, they are at a high risk of iron overload from transfusions. Iron chelation therapy, such as desferrioxamine is important to reduce the risk of complications.

Both ferrous fumarate and ferrous sulphate are forms of iron supplementation. These are counter-productive in this case as this patient is likely to suffer from complications of iron overload.

Folate and vitamin B12 are important components in the production of red blood cells. However, they would not play a role in limiting the complications of iron overload.
question:
A 16-year-old receives regular blood transfusions since she was diagnosed with beta-thalassaemia major as a baby.

What medication should she also be taking alongside her infusions?
question_notes:
Patients with beta thalassaemia-major need regular transfusions from birth. As a result, they are at a high risk of iron overload from transfusions. Iron chelation therapy, such as desferrioxamine is important to reduce the risk of complications.

Both ferrous fumarate and ferrous sulphate are forms of iron supplementation. These are counter-productive in this case as this patient is likely to suffer from complications of iron overload.

Folate and vitamin B12 are important components in the production of red blood cells. However, they would not play a role in limiting the complications of iron overload.
title: Beta-thalassaemia major
body:
Overview
  • Absence of beta-globin chains
  • Mutation located on chromosome 11

Features
  • Presents within the first year of life after HbF falls, with:
    • Failure to thrive
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Severe transfusion-dependent microcytic anaemia
  • HbF markedly raised (predominant)
  • HbA2 may be raised but is not the main feature
  • HbA absent

Management
  • Regular lifelong blood transfusions
    • Improves anaemia and growth
    • Leads to iron overload → risk of cardiac, hepatic, and endocrine organ failure
  • Iron chelation therapy essential (e.g. desferrioxamine, deferasirox, deferiprone)
  • Allogeneic stem cell / bone marrow transplantation in selected cases (curative)
  • Ongoing monitoring for complications (iron overload, infection, endocrinopathies)
concept: In beta-thalassaemia major, iron chelation therapy (e.g. desferrioxamine) is important to prevent the complications of iron overload due to repeat transfusions
links:
Rare Disease Video Library - NORD35
Beta-thalassaemia


Patient.info52
Thalassaemia review
media:
Thalassemia
AK lectures - YouTube10
 
Beta-thalassaemia
Osmosis - YouTube10

11591.concept_text: In beta-thalassaemia major, iron chelation therapy (e.g. desferrioxamine) is important to prevent the complications of iron overload due to repeat transfusions

questions: Which one of the following nails changes is least likely to occur in psoriasis?
notes:
The correct answer is Yellow nail syndrome. Yellow nail syndrome is characterised by slow-growing, thickened yellow nails often associated with lymphoedema and respiratory disorders such as chronic sinusitis or bronchiectasis. It is not commonly associated with psoriasis, which is a systemic inflammatory disease primarily affecting the skin and joints.

Discussing the incorrect options:

Loss of nail can occur in severe cases of psoriasis, particularly if there's extensive pitting or onycholysis. Psoriatic nails may become so weakened by these changes that they shed entirely.

Onycholysis, which refers to the separation of the nail from the nail bed, is one of the most common nail changes seen in psoriasis. It typically starts at the tip of the nail and progresses towards the root, leading to a whitish appearance due to air under the detached portion of the nail.

Pitting, or small depressions on the surface of the nails, is another classic feature of psoriatic nails. These pits result from increased shedding of cells from the base layer of the epidermis in tiny areas scattered across the nail plate.

Lastly, subungual hyperkeratosis, or thickening under the nails, can also occur in psoriasis due to excessive production and accumulation of keratinocytes (skin cells) beneath the nail plate. This causes an irregular, often painful thickening that lifts up and distorts the overlying nail.
question: Which one of the following nails changes is least likely to occur in psoriasis?
question_notes:
The correct answer is Yellow nail syndrome. Yellow nail syndrome is characterised by slow-growing, thickened yellow nails often associated with lymphoedema and respiratory disorders such as chronic sinusitis or bronchiectasis. It is not commonly associated with psoriasis, which is a systemic inflammatory disease primarily affecting the skin and joints.

Discussing the incorrect options:

Loss of nail can occur in severe cases of psoriasis, particularly if there's extensive pitting or onycholysis. Psoriatic nails may become so weakened by these changes that they shed entirely.

Onycholysis, which refers to the separation of the nail from the nail bed, is one of the most common nail changes seen in psoriasis. It typically starts at the tip of the nail and progresses towards the root, leading to a whitish appearance due to air under the detached portion of the nail.

Pitting, or small depressions on the surface of the nails, is another classic feature of psoriatic nails. These pits result from increased shedding of cells from the base layer of the epidermis in tiny areas scattered across the nail plate.

Lastly, subungual hyperkeratosis, or thickening under the nails, can also occur in psoriasis due to excessive production and accumulation of keratinocytes (skin cells) beneath the nail plate. This causes an irregular, often painful thickening that lifts up and distorts the overlying nail.
title: Psoriasis and psoriatic arthropathy: nail changes
body:
Psoriatic nail changes affect both fingers and toes and do not reflect the severity of psoriasis but there is an association with psoriatic arthropathy - around 80-90% of patients with psoriatic arthropathy have nail changes.

Nail changes that may be seen in psoriasis
  • pitting
  • onycholysis (separation of the nail from the nail bed)
  • subungual hyperkeratosis
  • loss of the nail

questions:
A 67-year-old woman is reviewed a week after being diagnosed with having a deep vein thrombosis of her left leg. After receiving low-molecular weight heparin for 5 days she has now been started on warfarin. She has a history of depression, osteoporosis, breast cancer and type 2 diabetes.

Which one of her current medications is most likely to have increased her risk of developing a deep vein thrombosis?
notes: One of the most important adverse effects of tamoxifen is the increased risk of VTE. Women should be counselled about this prior to starting treatment.
question:
A 67-year-old woman is reviewed a week after being diagnosed with having a deep vein thrombosis of her left leg. After receiving low-molecular weight heparin for 5 days she has now been started on warfarin. She has a history of depression, osteoporosis, breast cancer and type 2 diabetes.

Which one of her current medications is most likely to have increased her risk of developing a deep vein thrombosis?
question_notes: One of the most important adverse effects of tamoxifen is the increased risk of VTE. Women should be counselled about this prior to starting treatment.
title: Venous thromboembolism: risk factors
body:
Common predisposing factors include malignancy, pregnancy and the period following an operation. The comprehensive list below is partly based on the 2010 SIGN venous thromboembolism (VTE) guidelines:

General
  • increased risk with advancing age
  • obesity
  • family history of VTE
  • pregnancy (especially puerperium)
  • immobility
  • hospitalisation
  • anaesthesia
  • central venous catheter: femoral >> subclavian

Underlying conditions
  • malignancy
  • thrombophilia: e.g. Activated protein C resistance, protein C and S deficiency
  • heart failure
  • antiphospholipid syndrome
  • Behcet's
  • polycythaemia
  • nephrotic syndrome
  • sickle cell disease
  • paroxysmal nocturnal haemoglobinuria
  • hyperviscosity syndrome
  • homocystinuria

Medication
  • combined oral contraceptive pill: 3rd generation more than 2nd generation
  • hormone replacement therapy: the risk of VTE is higher in women taking oestrogen + progestogen preparations compared to those taking oestrogen-only preparations
  • raloxifene and tamoxifen
  • antipsychotics (especially olanzapine) have recently been shown to be a risk factor

It should be remembered however that around 40% of patients diagnosed with a PE have no major risk factors.
concept: Tamoxifen increases the risk of VTE + endometrial cancer

questions:
A 25-year-old man attends the Emergency Department with acute breathlessness. Yesterday he returned from Australia after a backpacking trip, during which he was fit and well. He has no other symptoms of note and is haemodynamically stable.

He has no history of cancer, heart failure or chronic lung disease. He has not had a VTE before and has no relevant family history.

He has a D-Dimer taken which is raised. A subsequent CTPA shows a small pulmonary embolism (PE) with no features of right-sided heart strain.

The consultant feels he can be managed as an outpatient with a DOAC and close follow-up. Which of the scoring systems below can help their decision making?
notes:
The correct answer is the PESI score, short for Pulmonary Embolism Severity Index. In patients diagnosed with PE, the PESI score can help predict long-term morbidity and mortality. It is recommended by the British Thoracic Society to assess who could be managed as outpatients.

The ABCD2 is used to triage patients presenting with an acute Transient Ischaemic Attack (TIA).

The CHA2DS2-VASc score is a decision aid to help those considering starting prophylactic anticoagulation in those with atrial fibrillation.

The GRACE score helps to estimate mortality from those who have had Acute Coronary Syndrome (ACS).

The Well's Score objectifies the risk of PE prior to diagnosis but is of no use in those who have had one confirmed on a scan.
question:

The correct answer is the PESI score, short for Pulmonary Embolism Severity Index. In patients diagnosed with PE, the PESI score can help predict long-term morbidity and mortality. It is recommended by the British Thoracic Society to assess who could be managed as outpatients.

The ABCD2 is used to triage patients presenting with an acute Transient Ischaemic Attack (TIA).

The CHA2DS2-VASc score is a decision aid to help those considering starting prophylactic anticoagulation in those with atrial fibrillation.

The GRACE score helps to estimate mortality from those who have had Acute Coronary Syndrome (ACS).

The Well's Score objectifies the risk of PE prior to diagnosis but is of no use in those who have had one confirmed on a scan.
title: Pulmonary embolism: management
body:
NICE updated their guidelines on the management of venous thromboembolism (VTE) in 2020. Some of the key changes include recommending the following:
  • the use of direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) as first-line treatment for most people with VTE
  • the use of DOACs in patients with active cancer, as opposed to low-molecular weight heparin as was the previous recommendation
  • outpatient treatment in low-risk pulmonary embolism (PE) patients
  • routine cancer screening is no longer recommended following a VTE diagnosis


Outpatient treatment in low-risk PE patients

Deep vein thrombosis has for a long time been treated on an outpatient condition. In contrast, patients with any form of PE were typically admitted. However, in recent years patients with a new diagnosis of PE who are deemed low-risk are now increasingly managed as outpatients. NICE formally supported this approach in their latest guidance.
  • NICE recommends using a 'validated risk stratification tool' to determine the suitability of outpatient treatment.
    • no guidance is given as to what tool should be used
    • the 2018 British Society guidelines support the use of the Pulmonary Embolism Severity Index (PESI) score
  • key requirements would clearly be haemodynamic stability, lack of comorbidities and support at home


Anticogulant therapy

The cornerstone of VTE management is anticoagulant therapy. This was historically done with warfarin, often preceded by heparin until the INR was stable. However, the development of DOACs, and an evidence base supporting their efficacy, has changed modern management.

Choice of anticoagulant
  • the big change in the 2020 guidelines was the increased use of DOACs
  • apixaban or rivaroxaban (both DOACs) should be offered first-line following the diagnosis of a PE
    • instead of using low-molecular weight heparin (LMWH) until the diagnosis is confirmed, NICE now advocate using a DOAC once a diagnosis is suspected, with this continued if the diagnosis is confirmed
    • if neither apixaban or rivaroxaban are suitable then either LMWH followed by dabigatran or edoxaban OR LMWH followed by a vitamin K antagonist (VKA, i.e. warfarin)
  • if the patient has active cancer
    • previously LMWH was recommended
    • the new guidelines now recommend using a DOAC, unless this is contraindicated
  • if renal impairment is severe (e.g. < 15/min) then LMWH, unfractionated heparin or LMWH followed by a VKA
  • if the patient has antiphospholipid syndrome (specifically 'triple positive' in the guidance) then LMWH followed by a VKA should be used

Length of anticoagulation
  • all patients should have anticoagulation for at least 3 months
  • continuing anticoagulation after this period is partly determined by whether the VTE was provoked or unprovoked
    • a provoked VTE is due to an obvious precipitating event e.g. immobilisation following major surgery. The implication is that this event was transient and the patient is no longer at increased risk
    • an unprovoked VTE occurs in the absence of an obvious precipitating event, i.e. there is a possibility that there are unknown factors (e.g. mild thrombophilia) making the patient more at risk from further clots
  • if the VTE was provoked the treatment is typically stopped after the initial 3 months (3 to 6 months for people with active cancer)
  • if the VTE was unprovoked then treatment is typically continued for up to 3 further months (i.e. 6 months in total)
    • NICE recommend that whether a patient has a total of 3-6 months anticoagulant is based upon balancing a person's risk of VTE recurrence and their risk of bleeding
    • the ORBIT score can be used to help assess the risk of bleeding
    • NICE state: 'Explain to people with unprovoked DVT or PE and a low bleeding risk that the benefits of continuing anticoagulation treatment are likely to outweigh the risks. '. The implication of this is that in the absence of a bleeding risk factors, patients are generally better off continuing anticoagulation for a total of 6 months


PE with haemodynamic instability

Thrombolysis
  • thrombolysis is now recommended as the first-line treatment for massive PE where there is circulatory failure (e.g. hypotension)
  • other invasive approaches should be considered where appropriate facilities exist

Patients who have repeat pulmonary embolisms, despite adequate anticoagulation, may be considered for inferior vena cava (IVC) filters. These work by stopping clots formed in the deep veins of the leg from moving to the pulmonary arteries. IVC filter use is currently supported by NICE but other studies suggest a weak evidence base - please see the link for more details.
concept: The Pulmonary Embolism Severity Index (PESI) score is recommended by BTS guidelines to be used to help identify patients with a pulmonary embolism that can be managed as outpatients
links:

2014 ESC Guidelines on the diagnosis and management of acute pulmonary embolism


Journal of the American College of Cardiology106
2017 Inferior Vena Cava Filters to Prevent Pulmonary Embolism


British Thoracic Society95
2018 Initial outpatient management of pulmonary embolism guidelines


NICE147
2020 Venous thromboembolism guidelines


British Committee for Standards in Haematology104

8025.concept_text: 'Provoked' pulmonary embolisms are typically treated for 3 months

8026.concept_text: 'Unprovoked' pulmonary embolisms are typically treated for 6 months

10423.concept_text: The Pulmonary Embolism Severity Index (PESI) score is recommended by BTS guidelines to be used to help identify patients with a pulmonary embolism that can be managed as outpatients

questions: You are examining a patient who complains of double vision. Whilst looking forward the patient's right eye turns downwards and outwards. On attempting to look to the patient's left the patient is unable to adduct the right eye and double vision worsens. On looking right the angle of the squint is less. What is the most likely underlying problem?
notes:
The correct answer is Right 3rd nerve palsy.

The third cranial nerve (oculomotor nerve) innervates most of the extraocular muscles, including the superior rectus, inferior rectus, medial rectus, and inferior oblique muscles. It also supplies the levator palpebrae superioris muscle and carries parasympathetic fibres to the pupil. In a right 3rd nerve palsy, the affected eye typically deviates 'down and out' due to the unopposed actions of the lateral rectus (innervated by the 6th nerve) and superior oblique (innervated by the 4th nerve) muscles. This matches the description of the right eye turning downwards and outwards when looking forward.

Additionally, the patient is unable to adduct the right eye when looking to the left because the medial rectus muscle, which is responsible for adduction, is innervated by the 3rd nerve. The worsening of double vision on left gaze is consistent with this, as the eyes become more misaligned when the patient attempts to use the affected muscle. When looking to the right, the angle of the squint decreases because this direction of gaze relies less on the affected muscles.

Left 3rd nerve palsy is incorrect because the symptoms described involve the right eye, not the left. In a left 3rd nerve palsy, the left eye would deviate downwards and outwards, and the patient would have difficulty adducting the left eye when looking to the right.

Left 6th nerve palsy is incorrect because the 6th nerve (abducens nerve) innervates only the lateral rectus muscle, which is responsible for abduction of the eye. A left 6th nerve palsy would cause the left eye to deviate inwards (esotropia) due to unopposed action of the medial rectus, and the patient would have difficulty abducting the left eye when looking to the left. This does not match the described presentation.

Right 4th nerve palsy is incorrect because the 4th nerve (trochlear nerve) innervates only the superior oblique muscle, which primarily intorts the eye and helps with depression when the eye is adducted. A right 4th nerve palsy would typically cause vertical diplopia that worsens on looking down and to the left, with the affected eye elevated relative to the normal eye. The patient would not have difficulty with adduction, and the eye would not typically turn outwards in primary gaze.

Right 6th nerve palsy is incorrect because, as mentioned earlier, the 6th nerve innervates only the lateral rectus muscle. A right 6th nerve palsy would cause the right eye to deviate inwards and the patient would have difficulty abducting the right eye when looking to the right. This contradicts the description of the eye turning outwards and the patient having difficulty with adduction rather than abduction.
question: You are examining a patient who complains of double vision. Whilst looking forward the patient's right eye turns downwards and outwards. On attempting to look to the patient's left the patient is unable to adduct the right eye and double vision worsens. On looking right the angle of the squint is less. What is the most likely underlying problem?
question_notes:
The correct answer is Right 3rd nerve palsy.

The third cranial nerve (oculomotor nerve) innervates most of the extraocular muscles, including the superior rectus, inferior rectus, medial rectus, and inferior oblique muscles. It also supplies the levator palpebrae superioris muscle and carries parasympathetic fibres to the pupil. In a right 3rd nerve palsy, the affected eye typically deviates 'down and out' due to the unopposed actions of the lateral rectus (innervated by the 6th nerve) and superior oblique (innervated by the 4th nerve) muscles. This matches the description of the right eye turning downwards and outwards when looking forward.

Additionally, the patient is unable to adduct the right eye when looking to the left because the medial rectus muscle, which is responsible for adduction, is innervated by the 3rd nerve. The worsening of double vision on left gaze is consistent with this, as the eyes become more misaligned when the patient attempts to use the affected muscle. When looking to the right, the angle of the squint decreases because this direction of gaze relies less on the affected muscles.

Left 3rd nerve palsy is incorrect because the symptoms described involve the right eye, not the left. In a left 3rd nerve palsy, the left eye would deviate downwards and outwards, and the patient would have difficulty adducting the left eye when looking to the right.

Left 6th nerve palsy is incorrect because the 6th nerve (abducens nerve) innervates only the lateral rectus muscle, which is responsible for abduction of the eye. A left 6th nerve palsy would cause the left eye to deviate inwards (esotropia) due to unopposed action of the medial rectus, and the patient would have difficulty abducting the left eye when looking to the left. This does not match the described presentation.

Right 4th nerve palsy is incorrect because the 4th nerve (trochlear nerve) innervates only the superior oblique muscle, which primarily intorts the eye and helps with depression when the eye is adducted. A right 4th nerve palsy would typically cause vertical diplopia that worsens on looking down and to the left, with the affected eye elevated relative to the normal eye. The patient would not have difficulty with adduction, and the eye would not typically turn outwards in primary gaze.

Right 6th nerve palsy is incorrect because, as mentioned earlier, the 6th nerve innervates only the lateral rectus muscle. A right 6th nerve palsy would cause the right eye to deviate inwards and the patient would have difficulty abducting the right eye when looking to the right. This contradicts the description of the eye turning outwards and the patient having difficulty with adduction rather than abduction.
title: Third nerve palsy
body:
Features
  • eye is deviated 'down and out'
  • ptosis
  • pupil may be dilated (sometimes called a 'surgical' third nerve palsy)

Causes
  • diabetes mellitus
  • vasculitis e.g. temporal arteritis, SLE
  • false localizing sign* due to uncal herniation through tentorium if raised ICP
  • posterior communicating artery aneurysm
    • pupil dilated
    • often associated pain
  • cavernous sinus thrombosis
  • Weber's syndrome: ipsilateral third nerve palsy with contralateral hemiplegia -caused by midbrain strokes
  • other possible causes: amyloid, multiple sclerosis

*this term is usually associated with sixth nerve palsies but it may be used for a variety of neurological presentations
media:
Third Cranial Nerve Palsy
U-M Kellogg Eye Center - YouTube70
 
3rd nerve palsy
Individual - YouTube20

1440.concept_text: Raised ICP can cause a third nerve palsy due to herniation
